Work-in-progress

Metaphorically speaking, the true function of a builder is to peel the onion. The most useful yet underutilized tool for any builder.

Suppose, you are in charge of owning a product development for a customer, what is the first thing you do? You don't just start building. You gather information on your customer. You do discovery. You understand their pain point. Customer want to make progress in their lives with the products they use. They do not care (to a certain extent) about the name, people who built it or fancy graphics. Customer want to eat better, sleep better, take care of their families, be happy and feel recognized.

In that case, as a builder, it is your responsibility to ensure customers are making progress when utilizing your product. If they are not making progress, you are not expressing your gratitude and neither empathizing with their pain.

So, what does peeling the onion has to do with building products? You are not literally peeling the onion, but asking the right questions, so you can gather all the requirements to build a consumable product and get it to the end customer. Let's start mental models that will help you ask the right questions:

  1. Inversion
  2. Feedback Loops
  3. Porter Principles
  4. Social Proof
  5. Second Order Thinking
